title: â€œHistoric Dayâ€: Reform Storms to Victory in Labour Heartland
author: By Michael Curzon | The European Conservative
content:
There are many results still to declare from Thursdayâ€™s elections across England. But already, Nigel Farageâ€™s populist Reform Party is the big winner of the day.
Indeed, after the partyÂ wonÂ the Runcorn and Helsby parliamentary by-election byÂ sixÂ votes, new Reform MP Sarah Pochin declared Farage as â€œthe next prime minister of this great country.â€
Thank you Runcorn & Helsby. Enough Tory failures, enough Labour lies.Reform UK is the party of change. pic.twitter.com/YFHLemZJKj
The result is close but momentous, not least given the fact that this was one of Labourâ€™s safest seats in England. Waking up this morning, Prime Minister Keir Starmer might well have questioned whether there is such a thing as a safe seat anymore. Reformâ€™s rapid rise certainly means there are far fewer of them.
Party chairman Zia Yusuf said this was â€œa historic day for Britainâ€â€”one which sets great expectations for wider victories at the next general election.
The Conservatives, Britainâ€™s â€˜officialâ€™ opposition party, finished more than 10,000 votes behind Reform, only beating the largely irrelevant Green Party by 27 votes, prompting Farage toÂ sayÂ there was â€œno doubtâ€ that
In most of the country we are now the main opposition party to this government.
The result certainly helps to embed in the minds of voters that the way to beat Labour is to vote Reformâ€”in other words, â€œif you vote Conservative, you will get Labour.â€
As of 10:00 a.m. (BST), Reform has also won 79 council seats, which is more than any other party. It is currently winningÂ close to 40% of the vote, more than 10 points ahead of the Tories.
This is already a major blow to the establishment parties. And itâ€™s only the beginning.

title: IMF and World Bank: Crony Covid Crackdown Enablers
author: By James Bovard | Brownstone Institute
content:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent complained last week that the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are suffering from â€œmission creep.â€ But Bessent announced that Trump will be â€œdoubling downâ€ on supporting the largest foreign aid gushers on earth. â€œFar from stepping back, â€˜America Firstâ€™ seeks to expand U.S. leadership in international institutions like the I.M.F. and World Bank,â€ Bessent declared.
Bessent complained that the IMF â€œdevotes disproportionate time and resources to work on climate change, gender, and social issues.â€ Unfortunately, Bessent said nothing about how the IMF and World Bank bankrolled many of the worst crony Covid crackdown policies.
But what should the US government expect when Congress and endless presidents give the World Bank and IMF billions of US tax dollars to play with? The US government is on the hook forÂ $52 billionÂ to the World Bank. The US has a financial commitment ofÂ $183 billionÂ to the IMF.
The IMF was created in 1944 to shore up currencies and help nations with temporary balance-of-payment problems. In the decades since the IMFâ€™s founding, global capital markets and fluctuating currency exchange rates have made the IMF a relic. But too many people have gotten rich from IMF largesse to permit the curtain to be closed on this institution.
The IMF enabled scores of governments that chose to pointlessly shut down their own economies after the outbreak of Covid-19. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva declared in April 2021, â€œWhile the recovery [from Covid] is underway, too many countries are falling behind and economic inequality is worsening. Strong policy action is needed to giveÂ everyone a fair shotâ€”a shot in the arm to end the pandemic everywhere, and a shot at a better future for vulnerable people and countries.â€
The IMFâ€™s â€œfair shotâ€ consisted of its international bureaucrats providing scores of billions of dollars in â€œemergency financingâ€ to 80 governments, most of whom exploited Covid to stretch their own power. The IMF provided emergency relief via theÂ Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust (CCRT)Â to 29 governments to supposedly help them â€œcombat the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.â€ The IMFâ€™s deluge of handouts to government helped fuel the worldwide inflation surge in recent years.
The World Bank President Ajay Banga â€œhas sought to emphasize the bankâ€™s focus on job creationâ€¦and toÂ prioritize private sectorÂ involvement in projects around the world,â€ theÂ New York TimesÂ reported. But the World Bankâ€™s notion of the private sector has often been either a fraud or a political smokescreen. In the late 1980s, the WorldÂ Bank touted its loans toÂ Communist nations as private sector-oriented loans â€“ one bait-and-switch too many, as I detailed in a 1988Â Wall Street JournalÂ article. And permitting the Bank to exonerate its handouts by counting illusory jobs created is a recipe for make-work scams.
The Covid pandemic provided the World Bank with the chance to play savior. In the first months of the pandemic, the Bank proudly announced that its â€œemergency operations to fight COVID-19 (coronavirus) haveÂ reached 100 developingÂ countries â€“ home to 70% of the worldâ€™s population.â€ From April 2020 to March 2021, the World Bank â€œcommitted over $200 billion, an unprecedented level of financial support, to public and private sector clients to fight the impacts of the pandemic.Â  Our support is tailored to theÂ health, economic, andÂ social shocksÂ that countriesÂ are facing.â€ The fact that the World Bank was effectively financing governments to pointlessly shock their own nations was omitted from celebratory press releases.
The IMF and World Bank have helped turn many foreign nations into kleptocracies â€“ governments of thieves. AÂ 2002Â American Economic ReviewÂ analysisÂ concluded that â€œincreases in [foreign] aid are associated with contemporaneous increases in corruption,â€ and that â€œcorruption is positively correlated with aid received from the United States.â€
Most importantly, neither the IMF nor the World Bank has any qualms about bankrolling tyranny. A 2015 report of theÂ United Nationsâ€™ Special RapporteurÂ on extreme poverty and human rights, Philip Alston, concluded that the World Bank â€œnow stands almost alone, along with the International Monetary Fund, in insisting that human rights are matters of politics which it must, as a matter of legal principle, avoid, rather than being an integral part of the international legal order.â€
The Bank justifies this position by insisting that it cannot involve â€œitself in the partisan politics or ideological disputes that affect its member countriesâ€ by improper methods such as â€œfavoring political factions, parties or candidates in elections,â€ or â€œendorsing or mandating a particular form of government, political bloc or political ideology.â€
But any time an international organization financially bails out a regime, it bolsters its power. After the United States invaded Afghanistan and Iraq, the Pentagon coined a term that perfectly captures the effect of foreign aid: â€œMoney as a Weapon System.â€ The 2015 UN report noted that â€œthe existing approach taken by the World Bank to human rights is incoherent, counterproductive and unsustainable. For most purposes, the World Bank is a human rights-free zone. In its operational policies, in particular, it treats human rights more like an infectious disease than universal values and obligations.â€
The World Bank actively blindfolds itself to avoid hearing about atrocities in nations ruled by governments that it is bankrolling. The Special Rapporteur noted, â€œBy refusing to take account of any information emanating from human rights sources, the Bank places itself in an artificial bubble.â€
The Trump administrationâ€™s lust for â€œdoubling downâ€ on the IMF and World Bank is dicey to reconcile with theirÂ terminating 90% of foreign aidÂ contracts from the US Agency for International Development (USAID). Cynics across the land rejoiced that Washington policymakers finally recognized one of the biggest swindles of the past 80 years.
If the Trump team canâ€™t even get sound policy on the World Bank, then what hope is there of them resolving any more complex challenges? I was briefly a consultant for the World Bank in the late 1980s, getting paid toÂ co-author a reportÂ on the follies of farm subsidies. At that point, Reagan administration officials had periodically caterwauled about the Bank for almost a decade, and they were followed by sporadic howling by the US Treasury Department ever since. Secretary Bessent complained on Wednesday that the World Bank â€œshould no longer expect blank checks for vapid, buzzword-centric marketing accompanied by halfhearted commitments to reform.â€ But after almost a half-century of failed US attempts to reform the Bank and IMF, there is no reason to expect any boondoggles to be left behind.

title: Is This the Man Who Created Covid-19 in Fauciâ€™s US Lab?
author: By Will Jones | Brownstone Institute
content:
Top US virologist Ralph Baric engineered the Covid-19 virus SARS-CoV-2 in his lab at the University of North Carolina as part of his work in connection with the 2018Â DEFUSE funding proposal. Thatâ€™s the story thatâ€™s been going round the internet for some months now (andÂ not just in alternative media) and it all looks very damning for Baric and those connected with his research.
Details of the DEFUSE project were first leaked byÂ Major Joseph Murphy, an employee of US military research agency DARPA, in the summer of 2021 and further details of earlier drafts have come to light this month thanks to public record requests fromÂ U.S. Right to KnowÂ (USRTK).
In DEFUSE, Baric proposed to create a virus that was, to most intents and purposes, SARS-CoV-2. The proposal included inserting a furin cleavage site into a coronavirus spike protein, an order for the restrictive enzyme BsmBI, the search for a binding domain that would infect ACE2 human receptors and a requirement for a viral genome around 25% different to SARS.
The SARS-CoV-2 virus contains a furin cleavage site in its spike protein, its genome includes the restrictive enzyme BsmBI, it has a receptor binding domain finely tuned to infect the ACE2 human receptor and its genome is around 25% different to SARS. A number of virologistsÂ have said that such features make SARS-CoV-2 a smoking gunÂ for an engineered virus.
BaricÂ obtained a patentÂ forÂ such novel virusesÂ in 2018, just as he was putting DEFUSE together. In DEFUSE he proposed to infect wild Chinese bats with his newly patented viruses.
Many regard this as case closed for the lab leak.
But this is not the full story. Thatâ€™s because Baricâ€™s DEFUSE proposal did not win the DARPA funding. And while it is rightly pointed out that, with or without the funding, much of the work was already in hand, itâ€™s what happened next with theÂ winningÂ DARPA proposal where the story really gets interesting.
US researcher Jim Haslam has done an incredible job on his Substack articleÂ Reverse engineering the origins of SARS-CoV-2Â documenting all the toings and froings among the virology community in connection with the creation of this peculiar virus and the subsequent cover-up. What follows is in large part indebted to his meticulous research, though any errors are of course my own.
TheÂ winning 2018 DARPA bidÂ was for a project calledÂ PREEMPTÂ led by Dr. Vincent Munster (pictured above) based at Anthony Fauciâ€™s NIH Rocky Mountain Lab. Both PREEMPT and Baricâ€™s losing DEFUSE project had the same basic idea: to try to prevent a (hypothetical) future pandemic by using an engineered SARS virus to vaccinate the bats from which it is believed such a virus was likely to spill over.
The idea being, of course, that the vaccinated bats would no longer be a reservoir for the virus, thus â€˜defusingâ€™ or â€˜preemptingâ€™ the zoonotic spillover. Sounds crazy? Too right â€“ far too much meddling with nature and placing too much faith in the ability of vaccines to prevent infection and transmission. But crazy or not, thatâ€™s what the scientists proposed, and PREEMPT won and DEFUSE lost.
The key difference between Baricâ€™s DEFUSE and Munsterâ€™s PREEMPT â€“ aside from PREEMPT coming in around $4 million cheaper at $10 million â€“ is that rather than relying on spraying bat caves with aÂ non-transmissibleÂ virus-vaccine, Munsterâ€™s plan involved making the virus-vaccineÂ transmitÂ between the bats via aerosols. This made it aÂ self-spreading vaccine, able (in theory) to reach all the bats without humans having to go and find all their caves and spray them. The risks of such a plan should have been obvious. Indeed, Baric himself, who went awfully quiet after his DEFUSE project leaked in mid-2021,Â resurfacedÂ in mid-2023 to say that such work involving engineering transmissible virus-vaccines was â€œtoo edgyâ€ for him.
After the DARPA funding went to PREEMPT, FauciÂ rode to Baricâ€™s rescueÂ with a bumper $82 million programme calledÂ CREID, awarded in summer 2019, in which both Baric and Munsterâ€™s teams would cooperate in the research into Munsterâ€™s concept of self-spreading bat vaccines.
Exactly what happened next is not publicly documented, so we do need to fill in some gaps. It appears that Munster took Baricâ€™s patented SARS virus-vaccine and made a transmissible version at his Rocky Mountain Lab (Baricâ€™s version was not intended to be transmissible). What is the evidence for that? Perhaps most telling is that, as HaslamÂ observes, SARS-CoV-2Â transmitsÂ efficientlyÂ inÂ onlyÂ fiveÂ known mammals, and those five â€“Â American deer,Â American deer mice,Â Syrian hamsters,Â American mink, andÂ Egyptian fruit batsÂ â€“ are all found in Munster (and Fauciâ€™s) Rocky Mountain Lab in Montana. SARS-CoV-2 doesnâ€™t infect lab animals common inÂ Chinese labsÂ or present in the WIV, such asÂ Chinese horseshoe bats. This would suggest that SARS-CoV-2 acquired its transmissibility in an American lab context and not a Chinese one or elsewhere.
The virus-vaccine having been made transmissible in Montana, it would then have been sent to the WIV to beÂ tested on Chinese bats, which were not available in American labs. There can be little doubt who would have done this testing at the WIV, as there was only one scientist with the necessary connections and expertise.
Dr. Danielle Anderson, known as Dani to her colleagues,Â gained fameÂ in June 2021 as the â€œlast and only foreign scientist in the Wuhan labâ€ as she went public toÂ make the caseÂ for a zoonotic origin. Dani was a member of theÂ LancetÂ origins commission, chaired by Jeffrey Sachs andÂ disbandedÂ by him in October 2021 over frustrations that the Western virologistsÂ like DaniÂ werenâ€™t cooperating. Dani was based on and off at the WIV in the high securityÂ BSL4Â lab (not Shi Zhengliâ€™s BSL2 lab), but sheÂ didnâ€™t work for the WIV. She worked for Duke-NUS, the Singapore-based medical school of North Carolinaâ€™s Duke University, under the virologist Dr. Linfa Wang. Linfa and Anderson were part of Baricâ€™s DEFUSE proposal, and Duke-NUS was later a partner in Fauciâ€™s CREID project.
Andersonâ€™sÂ role in DEFUSEÂ was to test the virus-vaccines on â€œwild-caught captiveâ€ Chinese horseshoe bats at the WIV. It is thus reasonable to assume it is her who would be responsible for testing Munsterâ€™s self-spreading virus-vaccine on the same Chinese bats. This would explain how the virus got to Wuhan.
It would explain, in other words, how a non-transmissible virus-vaccine designed by Ralph Baric at UNC as per the DEFUSE proposal became a transmissible virus and ended up on the loose in Wuhan. Namely, because it escaped via a laboratory-acquired infection during Andersonâ€™s testing of it on Chinese horseshoe bats in her WIV BSL4 lab, with Dani herself or a colleague as patient zero.
Admittedly, we donâ€™t have direct evidence of this â€“ we donâ€™t have direct evidence that a Munster-Baric SARS-2 virus-vaccine was being tested on Chinese bats in the WIV in 2019, nor that Dr. Anderson or a colleague was infected by it in the lab. But there is a heap of evidence that points to it as a likely scenario.
We know, for instance, that both Baric and Munster were proposing to vaccinate Chinese bats using an engineered virus based on SARS, with a furin cleavage site inserted to increase infectivity. We know that Munsterâ€™s PREEMPT proposal, in which the virus-vaccine was to be self-spreading, won the DARPA funding, beating Baricâ€™s DEFUSE proposal for a non-self-spreading virus-vaccine, and that in 2019 both teams were brought together in an $82 million grant from Fauciâ€™s NIAID.
We know that SARS-CoV-2 readily transmits in the lab animals found in Munsterâ€™s Rocky Mountain Lab but not in the lab animals found in the WIV. From this we can further conclude that Dr. Andersonâ€™s experiment to infect Chinese horseshoe bats with the new virus at the WIV presumably failed. This may be why she left Wuhan at the end of November, which was theÂ deadlineÂ for the â€˜scientific merit reviewâ€™ for CREID.
We also know that whereÂ Dani and her colleagues livedÂ in central Wuhan was an early epicentre for the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak, based onÂ social mediaÂ data.
It also appears that Daniâ€™s supervisor Linfa Wang may have quickly realised that SARS-CoV-2 was one of his viruses. This would explain why heÂ resignedÂ from his post as Director of Dukeâ€™s Emerging Infectious Disease programme, a position he had held for nearly a decade, on the same day that the genome was published, January 10th 2020. The reason for his abrupt resignation has never been disclosed.
Four days earlier he hadÂ told theÂ New York TimesÂ he was frustrated that scientists in China were not allowed to speak to him about the outbreak. He cautioned against panic, arguing the virus was likely not spreading between humans because health workers had not contracted the disease. But privately was he fretting that it was from his lab â€“ is that why he immediately resigned when the genome was published? It is hard to understand what else could have led him to quit so suddenly at that point, and the lack of explanation adds to the suspicion. He laterÂ called January 10thÂ â€œthe most important day in the Covid-19 outbreakâ€ because it was when the genome was published.
If Linfa was anticipating the bad news, it could have been because he and Dani had been aware of the leak at the time it happened. Analysis of mobile phone recordsÂ discoveredÂ an apparent shutdown of Dr. Andersonâ€™s BSL4 lab between October 7th and 24th 2019 (identified by the lack of mobile phone usage in the vicinity). Nothing further has come to light about this incident and what lay behind it, but if it does denote a laboratory-acquired infection that Anderson and Linfa (and presumably others) were aware of, it would explain a lot.
Such a scenario would also explain why Shi Zhengli had been eager to publish the sequence for the RaTG13 virus she held (the preprint appeared onÂ January 23rd 2020), despite this suggesting to many a non-natural origin of SARS-CoV-2.Â In the paper, the WIV scientist implied that SARS-CoV-2 had not emerged naturally from RaTG13, despite it being the closest known virus (â€œno evidence for recombination events was detected in the genomeâ€). Publishing it showed that her (BSL2) lab had nothing to hide as it was not involved in the work. The realisation that it was an engineered virus from the US may also have driven the panic that pushed the Chinese Government to lock Wuhan down around the same time.
Since 2021, Ralph Baric hasÂ thrown himselfÂ into developing vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 and other coronaviruses, even entertaining fantasies of â€œring vaccination,â€ as is done with Ebola, to try to stop the outbreak in its tracks. Is this his way of trying to make amends, however misguided? I wonder if we are also able to detect a hint of him pointing to who he thinks is really to blame for the debacle, when he remarks that â€œgovernments, rather than scientistsâ€ are primarily responsible for choosing which risky gain-of-function experiments to fund and run â€“ a reference perhaps to how Munsterâ€™s â€œedgyâ€ engineering of transmissible virus-vaccines was picked over his non-transmissible version.
â€œIt looks like American science is going to get shredded for a pandemic that started in China,â€ he toldÂ Timeâ€˜s Dan Werb, reverting to denial. When Werb suggested to him that despite the â€œconspiracy theoriesâ€ there are many people happy that he became a scientist in the first place, he replied: â€œA fair number that probably wished I hadnâ€™t. Letâ€™s be honest.â€
Is that the closest weâ€™ll get to a confession?

title: Leavitt: â€˜We Encourage Kamala to Continue Doing Speaking Engagementsâ€™
author: By Adan Salazar
content:
The White House fired back at Democrat presidential loser Kamala Harrisâ€™ abysmal speech criticizing President Donald Trump, encouraging the failed candidate to continue making public appearances.

title: Mike Waltz And Deputy Deleted After Signal Fiasco: Reports
author: By Zero Hedge
content:
Trump national security adviser Mike Walz and his deputy, Alex Wong, are out of a job in the White House following an incident in late march in which Waltz â€˜inadvertentlyâ€™ added The Atlanticâ€˜s Jeffrey Goldberg to a Signal chat which included discussions with top national security officials â€“ and VP JD Vance â€“ about plans for a military strike on Houthi targets in Yemem, CBS NewsÂ  and Politico report (so weâ€™re just waiting for the denial).
According to â€˜multiple sources familiar with their departure,â€™ following the Signal snafu, Waltz admitted behind closed doors to the authenticity of Goldbergâ€™s reporting â€“ however he never offered to resign, and President Trump did not ask him to step down.
Wong, meanwhile, served in the first Trump administration as deputy special representative for North Korea, as well as deputy assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs at the State Department.
The Signal fiasco set off a firestorm of calls for Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to resignâ€¦
Goldberg is still trying to blame Hegseth for everything, when Michael Waltz is the one responsible for the entire snafu. Now why would that be? Why would Goldberg repeatedly attack a victim of the breach instead of HIS FRIEND WHO SECRETLY INVITED HIM IN?Itâ€™s a real mystery. https://t.co/vjq9hO35P6
Among some 18 individuals listed as members of a Signal group that Goldberg was â€˜inadvertentlyâ€™ invited to includedÂ Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth,Â Vice President Vance, national security adviser Michael Waltz, Secretary of State is Marco Antonio Rubio, and Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard.

title: Russian Official Says Trumpâ€™s Mineral Deal Forces Ukraine to Pay For Future US Military Aid
author: By Sean Miller
content:
Following the signing of President Donald Trumpâ€™s mineral deal by Ukraine, Deputy Chairman of Russiaâ€™s Security Council, Dmitry Medvedev, said that Washington has broken the Zelensky Regime with the agreement. He posited that Washington is effectively forcing Kiev to pay the U.S. for its future military aid. Medvedevâ€™s analysis appears to pan out based on statements by Reuters, The New York Times and the Ukrainian official who signed the deal.
â€œTrump has broken the Kiev regime to the point where they will have to pay for U.S. aid with mineral resources,â€ Medvedev said on Telegram. â€œNow they (Ukrainians) will have to pay for military supplies with the national wealth of a disappearing country.â€
U.S. military aid, specifically air defense, is part of the mineral deal, however that aid will be derived from the newly created fund, which is paid for by Ukraineâ€™s own mineral resources.
â€œThe Fund will finance reconstruction efforts, with both sides contributing â€“ including via future U.S. military aid in the form of air defense, a notable change from the last deal draft,â€ the Kiev Post said Wednesday.
While the full text of the final mineral deal has not yet been officially published, several sources have reported on the fact the agreement does not provide specific â€˜security guaranteesâ€™ for Ukraine, a key stipulation of Ukrainian Dictator Vladimir Zelenskyâ€™s â€˜victory planâ€˜.
â€œThe Trump administration did not immediately provide details about the agreement, and it was not clear what it meant for the future of American military support for Ukraine. One person familiar with the negotiations, discussing them on the condition of anonymity, said the final deal does not include explicit guarantees of future U.S. security assistance. Another said the United States rejected that idea early in the process,â€ The New York Times said Wednesday.
â€œThe agreement did not, however, provide any concrete U.S. security guarantees for Ukraine, one of its initial goals,â€ Reuters said Wednesday.
Ukraineâ€™s First Deputy Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko, who was the official that signed the mineral deal on behalf of Kiev, discussed possible future U.S. military aid by explaining Washington will contribute to the fund, however she saved face by not specifically stating these U.S. contributions are investments aimed at revenue generation based off Ukraineâ€™s own mineral resources.
â€œHow will the Fund work? The United States will contribute to the Fund. In addition to direct financial contributions, it may also provide NEW assistance â€” for example, air defense systems for Ukraine,â€ she said Wednesday.

title: Labour Descends Into Civil War as Britons Vote in Local Elections
author: By Michael Curzon | The European Conservative
content:
Voters head to the polls today for local elections which are seen as aÂ perfect opportunityÂ for Nigel Farageâ€™s Reform UK to show its worth as a rising political force.
Terrible timing then, so far as Keir Starmer is concerned, for former Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair to blast the current governmentâ€™s net zero agenda as â€œirrationalâ€ because voters are being askedâ€”or, in many cases, forcedâ€”to make serious sacrifices despite making â€œminimalâ€ differences to the planet.
AÂ reportÂ from Blairâ€™s institute was received furiously by Labour, with local officialsÂ sayingÂ they were â€œincredibly p****d offâ€ about the impact it could have on the local elections. One party source alsoÂ bashedÂ the ex-PMâ€™s â€œpublic tantrumâ€ as â€œreally unhelpful.â€ The story splashed on most national newspapers on Wednesday.
The row got worse after Environment Secretary Steve ReedÂ praisedÂ Blair for making a â€œvalid and important contribution,â€ adding that he agreed â€œwith much of what he said.â€ And senior officials laterÂ refusedÂ to guarantee that Net Zero Secretary Ed Miliband will keep his job.
Farage was, of course, delighted by the very public row, hailing on social media:
Even Tony Blair now says the push for net zero has become â€œirrationalâ€ and â€œhysterical.â€
We are winning the argument!
The Reform leader believes net zero could be the new Brexit, â€œwhere parliament is so hopelessly out of touch with the country.â€
The Tony Blair Institute report said that simply limiting fossil fuels was â€œdoomed to failâ€ and pushed for a different approach.
By the time BlairÂ U-turned, attempting to paint Starmerâ€™s approach as â€œthe right one,â€ the damage had already been done. The green agendaâ€™sÂ roleÂ in this weekâ€™s major blackouts across the Iberian Peninsula will also have helped to paint a picture of just how dangerous the road to net zero is.
Not that Blair is guilt-free on this front, nor that his instituteâ€™s report is not still wedded to the view that Europe must act to avoid a climate emergency. Perhaps, as Net Zero Watchâ€™s Andrew MontfordÂ suggested, he is simply trying to â€œremain on the right side of history.â€
'He probably wants to remain on the right side of history!'Net Zero Watch's Andrew Montford reacts as Tony Blair calls for a 'radical reset' on the Government's green agenda. pic.twitter.com/ufffDTVf3w
A total of 1,641 council seats are up for grabs today in 23 local authorities in England. Polling stations will close at 10 p.m.

title: â€˜Future of the Partyâ€™: EPP Elects Weber â€˜Loyalistâ€™ as New Secretary General
author: By TamÃ¡s OrbÃ¡n | The European Conservative
content:
After reelecting Manfred Weber as party president the day before, the European Peopleâ€™s Party (EPP) congress in Valencia on Wednesday also elected its new secretary-general and ten vice presidents. The composition of the new EPP leadership reflects the partyâ€™s desire to become a more centralized political powerhouse to dominate all three EU institutions.
The EPPâ€™sÂ new secretary generalâ€”Weberâ€™s right-hand womanâ€”is Spanish MEP Dolors Montserrat, the leader of the Spanish PPâ€™s EU Parliamentary delegation and vice-chair of the EPP group in Brussels.
Montserratâ€™s election did not come as a surprise: she was tapped for the role by Weber himself a month ago, and since he was the only candidate for the presidency, his appointee also ended up on the â€˜ticketâ€™ unchallenged.
Similarly to Weberâ€™s dual role as group chairman and party presidentâ€”something that many staffers have complained about, both due to the centralization of power and the corresponding double salaryâ€”Montserrat is alsoÂ expectedÂ to keep her parliamentary jobs in addition to her new title.
The 51-year-old is the first woman to hold the second most powerful position in Europeâ€™s largest party family.Â AccordingÂ to Weber, she represents a â€œyoungerâ€ and more â€œmodernâ€ party, the â€œEPP of tomorrow.â€
In reality, however, Montserrat was selected because of her unquestionable loyalty to Weber and willingness to carry out his centralizing mission with ongoing reforms, widely seen as a massive power grab both within and outside the party.
AsÂ we described in more detail here, Weber is actively restructuring the operational model of the EPP by deepening his â€œpresidency coordinationâ€ systemâ€”having delegation leaders, national ministers, and even EPP commissioners agree on joint party lines before every major meeting or decisionâ€”as well as handing down policy priorities to members across all three EU institutions without much room for dissent, making sure that he at any point has personal control over the legislative process.
Weberâ€™s methods have often been described as â€œauthoritarian,â€ with the president aggressively pursuing his manufactured consensus. As one EPP official recently described it, anonymously, it often goes along the lines of: â€œHereâ€™s a draft, if I donâ€™t get a response in the next 30 hours, we will pass this.â€
While this centralization has been ongoing for the past three years, Weber is reportedly shifting gears in this new term, seeking to completely unify the party position across all institutions and in all political matters, under his strict supervision. And to carry this outâ€”being as unpopular among his own cadres as he isâ€”Weber needs someone at his side who would never question him.
And thatâ€™s what Montserrat is. When she was asked by reporters how she imagines her role as secretary generalâ€”previously a largely administrative but now increasingly politicized roleâ€”Montserratâ€™sÂ replyÂ showed that she knew perfectly what was expected. â€œI want to be a politician. Loyal to my president, Manfred, of course.â€
Corresponding to Weberâ€™s vision, EPPâ€™s ten new vice-presidents represent every EU institution: Parliament, Council, and Commission. However, unlike in the previous presidency, which was dominated by MEPs, an increased number of positions have now been given to government officials representing the national parties, which is meant to counterbalance the factâ€”even if just superficiallyâ€”that Weber is elevating himself to be on par or even above them.
The most powerful new vice presidents include Finnish Prime Minister Petteri Orpo; Antonio Tajani and Kostis Hatzidakis, deputy PMs of Italy and Greece, respectively; as well as Dubravka Å uica, the Croatian executive vice-president of the European Commission, and Magnus Brunner, the EU Commissioner for internal affairs from Austria.
As we noted above, the appointment of a large number of national party leaders to the EPP presidency is not accidental. Weber expects to have much more control over policy decisions even in the national capitals, and this is how he plans to achieve that: by symbolically elevating his partners but keeping the real power to himself.

title: Ukraine Officially Signs Trumpâ€™s Mineral Deal
author: By Sean Miller
content:
On Wednesday Kiev signed President Donald Trumpâ€™s mineral deal which aims to bring about the end of the Ukraine war while also paying the U.S. back for the military aid Washington supplied it.
â€œI am glad to announce the signing of todayâ€™s historic economic partnership agreement between the United States and Ukraine establishing the United States Ukraine Reconstruction Investment Fund,â€ U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Wednesday. â€œThis partnership allows the United States to invest alongside Ukraine to unlock Ukraineâ€™s growth assets, mobilize American talent, capital and governance standards that will improve Ukraineâ€™s investment climate and accelerate Ukraineâ€™s economic recovery.â€
Thanks to @POTUS @realDonaldTrumpâ€™s tireless efforts to secure a lasting peace, I am glad to announce the signing of todayâ€™s historic economic partnership agreement between the United States and Ukraine establishing the United States-Ukraine Reconstruction Investment Fund to helpâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/N1jPa35DYh
The final agreement includes a 50/50 split of mineral resource revenue between Washington and Kiev, as well as future U.S. military aid. Both of these provisions were added back after being removed due to Ukrainian Dictator Vladimir Zelensky continuing his war.
â€œThe Fund will finance reconstruction efforts, with both sides contributing â€“ including via future U.S. military aid in the form of air defense, a notable change from the last deal draft,â€ the Kiev Post said.
The new economic partnership has geopolitical implications as well.
â€œTodayâ€™s agreement signals clearly to Russian leadership that the Trump administration is committed to a peace process centered on a free, sovereign and prosperous Ukraine over the long term,â€ the Treasury Secretary said. â€œItâ€™s time for this cruel and senseless war to end.â€
In the hours prior to the official signing, Moscow urged Kiev to begin direct peace talks with the Kremlin.
On February 28Â Ukraineâ€™s Dictator went to WashingtonÂ where he insulted America in the White House, then refused to sign the mineral deal and was escorted out of the building.
Following his diplomatic debacle, Zelensky managed to continue botching the deal, going so far as to evenÂ have a number of provisions for his country removedÂ from it. Later, KievÂ sent â€˜a teamâ€˜ of delegates to Washington to actually negotiate the deal without the Dictator present.
On April 18 Ukrainian officials agreed to a preliminary mineral deal, paving the way for the official signing of the final agreement.
Moscow has also been affected by President Trumpâ€™s geopolitical operations. On Tuesday the Kremlin announced it had backtracked on a previous policy and is now willing to engage in direct peace negotiations with the government in Kiev after Trumpâ€™s envoy Steve Witkoff held numerous talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

title: House Overwhelmingly Passes â€œTake It Down Actâ€ Mandating Rapid Online Deepfake, Non-Consensual Imagery Takedowns
author: By Dan Frieth | Reclaim The Net
content:
A sweeping new internet regulation, theÂ Take It Down Act, is now poised for final approval as it awaits President Donald Trumpâ€™s signature following an overwhelming 409-2 vote in the House.
This legislation obliges social media companies to swiftly remove any content flagged as nonconsensual sexual imagery, including AI-manipulated photos. President Trump has expressed full support, declaring heâ€™ll sign the bill and jokingly remarked during a congressional address, â€œIâ€™m going to use that bill for myself too if you donâ€™t mind because nobody gets treated worse than I do online, nobody.â€
Framed as a measure to tackle the alarming rise in digital image abuse, the bill represents one of the few bipartisan tech safety efforts to pass both chambers in recent years. However, its broad scope and enforcement mechanisms have sparked concern among those who view it as fertile ground for censorship masked as protection.
By mandating that flagged content be taken down within 48 hours of a demand being made, it essentially creates a legal requirement for rapid, largely unchecked removal of material, whether real or artificially generated.
Just like theÂ DMCA, the law adds no obligation to actually check the takedown demand is not suppressing legitimate speech.
While stopping nonconsensual intimate imagery (NCII) is vital, the billâ€™s approach threatens to erode free expression and invite abuse.
The fact that enforcement of the law falls under the Federal Trade Commission, platforms closely aligned with those in power at the time could evade scrutiny, while others might be overwhelmed by false claims and unable to operate effectively.
The Electronic Frontier Foundation echoed these warnings, highlighting the lawâ€™s implications for encrypted services. These platforms, which cannot see the content of user communications, would be held to the same takedown obligations. According to the EFF, this could force services to choose between abandoning encryption or risking legal penalties. â€œPlatforms may respond by abandoning encryption entirely in order to be able to monitor contentâ€”turning private conversations into surveilled spaces,â€ the organization warned, pointing out that such platforms often serve as critical lifelines for vulnerable individuals, including abuse survivors.
Despite such warnings, the bill found a broad base of supporters. First Lady Melania Trump has championed the legislation, and several tech companies and advocacy groups have lined up behind it. Googleâ€™s Kent Walker called it â€œa big step toward protecting individuals from nonconsensual explicit imagery,â€ and Snap also voiced support. X CEO Linda Yaccarino also supports the bill.
Still, not everyone agreed. Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky, one of only two lawmakers to oppose the bill, pointed to potential overreach and loss of liberties. â€œI feel this is a slippery slope, ripe for abuse, with unintended consequences,â€ he wrote on X, capturing the fears of those who see in the bill an expansive censorship framework rather than a narrowly tailored fix.

title: Merz Warns of Democratic Crisis as He Seals Pact With the Socialists
author: By Javier Villamor | The European Conservative
content:
Friedrich Merz, CDU leader and Germanyâ€™s incoming chancellor, issued a stark warning on April 28th about the state of democracy in his country.Â He declaredÂ that â€œtrust in our democratic system is damaged like never before in our post-war history.â€ Speaking in Berlin at the event to ratify the new coalition agreement, Merz painted a bleak picture, saying that â€œthe pillars we have relied on for decades are now faltering around us.â€
The most recent survey on trust in democracy within the European Union,Â Flash Eurobarometer 550, conducted between June 25th and July 2nd, 2024, shows that 55% of EU citizens have confidence in democracy remaining strong in the EU over the next five years, while 41% expressed some level of distrust. In other words, four out of ten Europeans have no trust not inÂ democracy as such, but rather European institutions. Establishment political leaders tend not to make this distinction, preferring to avoid uncomfortable questions.
The CDU leader did not hesitate to point to multiple threats: an imperialist war in Eastern Europeâ€”a reference to Russiaâ€”but also growing domestic discontent, with citizens described as â€œfrightened, insecure, and even radicalized.â€ Merz warned that Germany faces real risks of sabotage and disinformation campaigns orchestrated from Moscow, calling for a â€œdetermined defense of our democracy against those who seek to divide Europe.â€
However, while paying lip service to the defense of Europe and the need for leadership, Merz has chosen a path that some observers label pragmatic, but many see as a sign of weakness: a coalition pact with the Social Democratic Party (SPD). After the February 23rd elections, in which the AfD (Alternative fÃ¼r Deutschland) surged to become the second-largest political force with over 20% of the vote, Merz concluded an agreement with CDUâ€™s traditional adversaries to form a â€œgrand coalitionâ€ that should see him elected chancellor on May 6th.
It is worth noting that according to the latest opinion polls,Â AfD has now overtaken the CDU.
MerzÂ has justified the agreement as a necessary evil to preserve national stability and prevent the further rise of political extremes. â€œThis is not the time for euphoria,â€ he told his supporters, asserting that Germany must once again â€œassume leadership responsibilityâ€ within the European Union. His stated priorities include increasing defense spending, modernizing infrastructure, and implementing stimulus measures for a weakened economy.
His government, whichÂ will includeÂ figures like Johann Wadephul, a former soldier and strong supporter of Ukraine, promises to strengthen the Atlantic alliance. However, Merz warned that with Donald Trumpâ€™s return to the U.S. presidency, â€œwe can no longer automatically rely on the transatlantic relationship.â€ This has reinforced the CDU narrative of a more autonomous Europe, although the lack of specifics regarding his European defense proposals raises doubts among more critical sectors.
The CDU-SPD coalition represents an attempt toÂ avoid political chaos, but at the same time it dilutes the conservative profile that many voters had hoped for following Merzâ€™s electoral victory. Rather than a clear change of direction, Germany seems to be heading towards a nuanced continuity, where centrist consensus prevails over a recovery of firm values.
However, Merz himself admitted that if the new government fails to meet the demands of the majority of voters, Germany could end up in a situation where â€œperhaps at some point we are no longer able to govern.â€ This admission highlights the fragility of the balance achieved. Both within the AfD and other sectors, there is growing hope for early elections by 2027.

title: The Canadian Election Does Not Matter
author: By Scott Greer | Highly Respected
content:
The Liberals won the Canadian election Monday, despite early polling favoring Pierre Poilievre and the Conservatives. The cause of Poilievreâ€™s reversal of fortune owes to two factors. One, the Liberals replaced the unpopular Justin Trudeau with Mark Carney as prime minister before the election. Two, Canadians associated the Conservatives with Donald Trump, whoâ€™s seen as a national enemy.
The latter factor has made a number of American conservatives lash out at Trump. Apparently, itâ€™s a massive loss that Pierre Poilievre is not the new prime minister. Except it isnâ€™t. The election doesnâ€™t actually matter to Americans. No matter who would be the new prime minister, Canada would attempt a tough line against Trump. Both serious options in Canada suck. The Conservatives are the equivalent of moderate Democrats. They are not Trumpists at all.
There is no real reason to be upset that Poilievre lost.
Poilievre was no Trump fan. HeÂ vowedÂ to â€œretaliateâ€ against American tariffs and repeatedly criticized the president for suggesting Canada should become the 51st state. His stance was not significantly different from that of the Liberal Party. Neither party looked to be a Trump ally. Each was going to be hostile to the current administration. If your main concern was getting a friendlier prime minister, there wasnâ€™t much of a choice here.
If you were concerned with Canada adopting a more sensible immigration policy, Poilievre wasnâ€™t great either. He has longÂ championed immigrationÂ to meet Canadaâ€™s â€œbusiness needs.â€ He believes employers should set the rates of immigration, which means they would happily welcome in hundreds of thousands of cheap foreign labor. At times, he did sound like he might support some cuts to migration. He believes the countryâ€™s immigration rates should be tied to housing development. Canada faces aÂ housing shortageÂ largely due to mass immigration. That might sound radical, but the Liberals also suggest a similar solution. TrudeauÂ moderatedÂ his immigration enthusiasm during his last year in office. CarneyÂ continued this trendÂ and campaigned on making immigration â€œsustainable.â€ The only notable difference between the parties is that the Conservatives emphasize cultural â€œintegrationâ€ more than the Liberals.
However, Poilievre still catered to multiculturalism by playing dress up when meeting various minority groups, particularly with Sikhs. Trudeau was widely-mocked for his pandering outfits, but Poilievre did the same thing in his appeals to minorities.
One of Poilievreâ€™s main issues throughout the campaign was the carbon tax, an onerous penalty imposed by Trudeau. CarneyÂ repealed the carbon tax when he took power, eliminating Poilievreâ€™s primary campaign pitch and further diminishing the differences between the two.
There is a genuine conservative party in Canada. Itâ€™s called the Peopleâ€™s Party, and it got lessÂ than one percent of the vote. Canadaâ€™s system, like ours, makes it tough for third parties. Besides the two major parties, only the Bloc Quebecois and the far-left New Democratic Party make an impact.
The fact a genuine conservative party does so poorly and that the â€œConservative Partyâ€ is so liberal speaks to the inherent â€œlibtardismâ€ of Canadians. This is a country whose national identity is based aroundÂ notÂ being Americans. Canadians and Americans have a lot in common. We both speak English and both countries were founded by Anglo-Protestants. Our cultures and accents are pretty similar. Canadians have to figure out ways to differentiate themselves. So they like to do the opposite of what Americans do. They love to think of themselves as more progressive and tolerant than their redneck neighbors. This makes them champion mass immigration, infringe on individual liberties, and boo our national anthem. If Trump does cool stuff as president, itâ€™s guaranteed that Canada will move in a different direction simply because it doesnâ€™t want to be like America.
Itâ€™s true that Trumpâ€™s tariffs influenced Canadaâ€™s elections. But of all the possible criticisms to make of this policy, making Pierre Poilievre lose is at the bottom of the list. Poilievre may have lost even without the tariffs. Canadians wouldâ€™ve been disgusted with Trump as president regardless of the trade war. Merely being perceived as Trump-friendly is a disadvantage. In order to help the Conservatives win elections, Trump would have to not be Trump.
Our country shouldnâ€™t be run on the basis of what will hurt the Conservative Party of Canada. America First means America First. Anything bold and controversial the president does will be unpopular with our northern neighbors. We shouldnâ€™t care what they think. Canada is an unimportant vassal state that bases its whole identity on not being us. They can care about us all they want. We donâ€™t need to care about them. American right-wingers should care about elections in countries that matter with serious right-wing parties, like Germany and France. We donâ€™t need to care about the election results in Malta or in Zanzibar.
It would be nice if Canada did have a Trump-friendly right-wing government. But there was no chance of that. Whoever won would be an anti-Trump liberal. Thatâ€™s why the election doesnâ€™t matter.
If youâ€™re Canadian and upset over the election results, I can understand. But itâ€™s silly to be upset over the results if youâ€™re an American. We have a right-wing administration in our country, and thatâ€™s what really matters.

title: Kremlin Backtracks, Now Ready to Negotiate With â€˜Illegitimateâ€™ Ukraine, Thanks to Trump
author: By Sean Miller
content:
In March Russian President Vladimir Putin announced he is no longer willing to negotiate peace with the â€œillegitimateâ€ government of Ukraine, instead insisting on a U.N./U.S./E.U.-backed temporary government for Kiev which Moscow would then negotiate with. On Tuesday the Kremlin reversed this stance, in part, due to the geopolitical brokering of President Donald Trump. Before the current administration in Washington, the world was sleepwalking toward nuclear war, indicating the only deescalation factor has been the White House.
â€œWhen asked about who Russia would consider holding direct negotiations with, given Zelenskyâ€™s status, Peskov admitted that while there are certain legal issues related to his legitimacy, â€˜the interests of entering the peaceful settlement process are above all elseâ€™,â€ RT said Tuesday.
The move by Moscow to prioritize peace over principle comes after months of footwork by the Trump administration to bring about a settlement in the Ukraine war. Most recently, Trumpâ€™s special envoy Steve WitkoffÂ arrivedÂ in Moscow on Friday for more peace talks with Putin. This is the fourth time he has traveled to the capital city for these negotiations. Witkoff deliveredÂ Trumpâ€™s peace proposal, which would see Crimea and a number of other regions of Eastern Ukraine currently held by Russia to be recognized as part of Russia. President TrumpÂ saidÂ Friday morning that he hopes to end the Ukraine war very soon and that he believes the U.S. will end up with a lot of good deals, including trade deals, as a result of the peace plan.
Special Envoy @generalkellogg: What @POTUS wants is a comprehensive ceasefire for a minimum of 30 days and then we can extend thatâ€¦ when you look at everything the Ukrainians are willing to work with, now it's over to the Russians, over to Putinâ€¦ I think we're close. pic.twitter.com/lJuRGfk8iF
â€œThe primary thing is to begin this negotiation process,â€ Peskov said, as well as clarifying that all other questions are â€œsecondary.â€ He said however that Moscow still does not believe Kiev is ready for peace negotiations.
Regardless of Moscowâ€™s confidence in Kiev, the resumption of a willingness to engage turns back a months-long resistance which stemmed from a breakdown in trust.
â€œIt would be possible to discuss the possibility of introducing temporary management in Ukraine under the auspices of the U.N., with the United States, even with European countries, of course, with our partners and friends. And for what? In order to hold democratic elections, in order to bring to power a capable and trusted government, and then start negotiations on a peace treaty with them, to start signing legitimate documents that will be recognized all over the world,â€ the Russian PresidentÂ saidÂ in Russian and translated to English.
Interestingly, in December Putin said that he only hadÂ one requirementÂ to signing a peace plan, that Kiev hold elections for their Dictator. Zelensky, however, has repeatedly refused to hold elections, causing Trump to call him a â€œDictator without electionsâ€ in February.
To clarify,Â Zelenskyâ€™sÂ PresidencyÂ ended in May. The Dictator refused to step down due to war-time provisions in the Ukrainian Constitution. He reiterated his anti-election stance inÂ NovemberÂ during a speech before the Ukrainian Parliament.
While Russia had been reluctant to negotiate with Ukraine for a month, it still held diplomatic talks with the U.S.
Soon afterÂ Kiev had agreedÂ to a temporary ceasefire that Trump brokered in March, which Moscow was then allowed to have a say in the details of before itselfÂ agreeingÂ to it, Ukraine broke the agreement by bombing Russian energy infrastructure targets,Â repeatedly. Trump nevertheless continued his agenda of peace for the region.
On Monday Vice President JD Vance said that Ukraine will not win this war.
â€œIf this doesnâ€™t stop, the Ukrainians arenâ€™t winning the war,â€ Vance said during an interview with Charlie Kirk during the conservative activistâ€™s podcast on Monday. â€œI think thereâ€™s this weird idea among the mainstream media that if this thing goes on for just another few years, the Russians will collapse, the Ukrainians will take their territory back, and everything will go back to the way that it was before the war. That is not the reality that we live in â€¦ You could have millions of more people killed if this thing goes on for another few years, and it could risk escalating into a nuclear war. It has to stop.â€
While JD Vance is not bullish on Ukraineâ€™s chances of winning, Putinâ€™s national security adviser Nikolay Patrushev insinuated Tuesday that Europe is bullish on nuclear war, saying that they are delirious with nuclear apocalypse scenarios.

title: Democrats Are Starting to Split Over The Issue of LGBTQIAAP2SN+
author: By Jonathon Van Maren | Lifesite
content:
(LifeSiteNews) â€” As the Democrats continue to grapple with the scale of their 2024 election losses and hone their messaging for the midterms, there is a growing split in the party over one key issue: transgenderism.
Old school Democrats, many of whom likely never bought into the premises of the transgender movement to begin with, want to pivotâ€”or at least want the â€œTâ€ in LGBT to be a bit quieter for a while. Even hardline progressive Democrats with presidential ambitions, such as Alexandra Ocasio-Cortez and Pete Buttigieg, quietly dropped their â€œpronounsâ€ from their social media bios.
Other progressives are desperately trying to persuade Democrats to hold the line. Podcaster Jennifer Welch recently melted down during an interview with prominent Democrat (and former Obama chief of staff) Rahm Emmanuel when he suggested that voters had disliked their focus on trans issues. â€œThat is such bull****! That is total bull****!â€ sheÂ shot back. â€œThat is buying into the right-wing media narrative and Iâ€™m so sick of Democrats like you selling out and saying this â€¦ It upsets me. It upsets me so much.â€
Late night host John Oliver, who has been one of the most prominent celebrity supporters of transgender ideology,Â including sex changes for children, similarly urged Democrats to stick with the movement. Oliver went so far as to insist that the issue was not difficult to defend at all, andÂ went off on one of his signature rants to prove it. It turns out defending transgenderism to a hand-picked audience with giant â€œAPPLAUSEâ€ signs on either side of your set stage is pretty easy, actually.
But in the real world, the trans movementÂ didÂ hurt the Democrats. According to theâ€¯Associated Pressâ€™ VoteCast, a survey of over 120,000 people who voted this fall found that more than half of voters said that â€œsupport for transgender rights in government and societyâ€ has â€œgone too far.â€ Only 2 in 10 said that support hadnâ€™t gone far enough, and only 2 in 10 said â€œitâ€™s about right.â€ 85 percent of those who voted for Trump said support for the transgender agenda has â€œgone too far.â€
A quarter ofÂ HarrisÂ voters agreed.
One Trump adÂ highlightedÂ Harris advocating for taxpayer-funded sex change surgeries for prisoners, and featured photos of trans-identifying and cross-dressing members of the Biden administration. The ad ends with the slogan: â€œKamala Harris is for They/Them. President Trump is for you.â€ Bill Clinton was so alarmed by the impact of the ads that,Â according to theâ€¯New York Times, he reached out to the Harris camp and urged them to repudiate their support for the policy. He was told the ad would be inconsequential. TheÂ ads moved voters 2.7 percent.
Those numbers explain why Emanuel, Clinton, and others want Democrats to back away from the transgender movementâ€”and why ambitious Dems are edging slowly away from aspects of the trans agenda. California Governor Gavin Newsom is as slippery as they come, but he is very adept at reading polls, which is why heÂ suddenly had Charlie Kirk on his podcast to agree with himÂ on how unfair it is for men to be permitted in womenâ€™s sports.
I have been saying for years that many of the politicians who toe the line of transgender ideology donâ€™t actually believe many of the premises they obediently parrot in public. They donâ€™t actually believe that women can have penises, or that men can get pregnant. They donâ€™t actually believe that a brawny bearded bloke who changed his pronouns on his official documents is a womanâ€”not really. So when trans ideology becomes a political liability, we discover which politicians were true believers.
UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, for example, embraced the UK Supreme Courtâ€™s affirmation that â€œtranswomenâ€ arenâ€™t women with barely concealed relief. Trans activists attacked Starmer for his willingness to turn on them so swiftly. But the truth is that Starmer probably never fully accepted transgender ideology to begin with. The trans movement was not a grassroots movementâ€”it was a top-down imposition of an ideology. Now, progressive parties are facing a moment of truth. It will be fascinating to discover how the Democrat civil war will resolve itself.

title: â€˜They Must Adapt, Not The Other Way Around!â€™ â€” Lower Austria to Introduce Fines For Radical Islamists Who Refuse to Integrate
author: By Thomas Brooke | Remix
content:
Lower Austriaâ€™s state parliament is set to adopt a sweeping legislative package aimed at combating radical Islam and strengthening integration obligations.
The legislation, which will be voted upon on April 30, was unveiled by state parliamentary party leaders Jochen Danninger (Ã–VP) and Reinhard Teufel (FPÃ–), marking a hardline stance against what they describe as â€œrefusal to integrate.â€
â€œIn Lower Austria, integration means adapting to our way of life and culture â€” not the other way around,â€ said Danninger, emphasizing the provinceâ€™s commitment to upholding traditional customs in kindergartens and schools, such as the celebration of St. Nicholas, Easter, and Christmas. Under the new law, failure to attend mandatory school or kindergarten meetings could result in fines of up to â‚¬2,500, with imprisonment of up to six weeks for repeated violations.
The legislative package also includes provisions for a ban on headscarves for girls, mandatory parental cooperation in schools, expansion of extremism prevention programs, a clear enforcement of German as the language of instruction and social interaction, and the codification of Austrian traditions in early education.
Danninger called the initiative a defense of â€œour blue and yellow identityâ€ â€” a reference to the stateâ€™s flag â€” adding that Lower Austria is once again â€œa pioneer among the federal states.â€
FPÃ– state representatives Martin Antauer and Michael Sommer voiced their support at a press conference, linking the measures to long-standing Freedom Party demands. â€œSince 2015, we have seen a decline in public safety and cohesion,â€ said Antauer. â€œThe federal government remains blind to the dangers of political Islam. We in Lower Austria are acting.â€
Antauer praised recent changes in kindergartens, schools, and public dress codes, citing the establishment of the State Security Council and an observatory on radicalism. Sommer, FPÃ–â€™s education spokesman, described the measures as a â€œmilestoneâ€ for protecting children and criticized Viennaâ€™s education system, which he said suffers from the consequences of failed integration: â€œOvercrowded classrooms, widespread lack of German skills, and cultural tensions.â€
Remix News reported last month how, for the first time, Muslim students had become the largest religious group in Viennaâ€™s schools. Muslim students now account for 41.2 percent of all students, while Christian students fell to 34.5 percent. The trend is only growing and is accompanied by rising problems, including violence in schools, anti-Semitism, and contempt for women.
Sommer further demanded that federal authorities ensure ideological neutrality in schools, prohibit halal-only meal plans, and protect traditional Austrian festivities from being overshadowed by religious sensitivities. â€œOur traditions â€“ like Advent or St. Nicholas â€“ must be taught and lived freely,â€ he said.
The motion also includes a proposal urging the federal government to implement a nationwide ban on political Islam. FPÃ–â€™s Reinhard Teufel said the move aims to send a â€œred cardâ€ to radical ideologies: â€œMass immigration has brought political Islam to our doorstep. We owe it to our people to act decisively.â€

title: France Eyes Musk-Style â€˜DOGEâ€™ Tactics to Trim Government Spending
author: By HÃ©lÃ¨ne de Lauzun | The European Conservative
content:
Criticism of the Trump administration may be very fashionable in France at the moment, but his political recipes are being emulated. Public Accounts Minister AmÃ©lie de Montchalin has announced that a third of government agencies should be merged or dissolved to reduce public spending.
Interviewed on CNews and Europe 1 on Sunday, April 27th, the minister announced that the government wantsÂ to abolish or mergeÂ one-third of the Stateâ€™s agencies and operators â€œby the end of the yearâ€ as part of the next finance bill for 2026. The aim is not only to reduce the public deficit, but also to move towards greater administrative simplification and efficiency.
This programme is not unlike that of Elon Musk, who was appointed head of DOGEâ€”the Department of Government Efficiencyâ€”by Donald Trump. Without obviously following in the footsteps of the American president, the minister provides some common-sense food for thought.
The finance bill for 2025 listed 434 State operators, receiving â‚¬77 billion in public funding and employing 180,000 people. With the planned restructuring, the state could generate â€œsavings of â‚¬2 to 3 billion,â€ according to the minister. â€œToday, there are 180,000 people working in the agencies and operators. Thatâ€™s more than the number ofÂ gendarmesÂ in the country!â€ she exclaimed to justify this upcoming tightening. â€œThe government is going to clean up our organisation, because the French are asking for it,â€ she added, while denying that she wanted to use the â€œchainsaw.â€ She explained that there were a number of levers available, such as the non-renewal of retirements and the pooling of skills.
Montchalinâ€™s speech earned her strong criticism from the Left and the unions, who are always quick to react when it comes to cutting public sector jobs. For the Communist newspaperÂ Lâ€™HumanitÃ©, this is no more and no less than a drastic â€œpurge.â€Â For the moment,Â no agency has been specifically targeted. The minister has made it clear that universities will not be affected by the budget cuts, but rumours are circulating about the uncertain future of agencies such asÂ the Agence Bio, founded in 2021 to promote the organic sector. In January, French Minister of Agriculture Annie Genevard commented on the relevance of â€œthe proliferation of bodies dealing with organic farming, most of which receive government funding and some of which carry out identical missions.â€ Ademe, the French Environment and Energy Management Agency, is also said to be in the hot seat. The environmental transition sector is the one that consumes the most public-sector jobs.

title: EU Ombudsman Delays Probe into Missing Docs on Romaniaâ€™s Election Annulment
author: By TamÃ¡s OrbÃ¡n | The European Conservative
content:
MCC Brussels has submitted a formal complaint to the European Unionâ€™s Ombudsman regarding the European Commissionâ€™s refusal to disclose key documents related to Digital Services Act (DSA) proceedings concerning Romaniaâ€™s canceled presidential elections from last year. In its Monday, April 28thÂ press releaseÂ MCC argued that voters deserve to know whether there was any foreign interferenceâ€”either from Moscow or Brusselsâ€”beforeÂ they go to the ballots again this weekend.
MCC Brussels later confirmed to this publication that the Ombudsman has admitted the case and will launch a probe into whether the Commissionâ€™s decision to withhold the information is lawful, but not in time to make any difference. Conveniently enough, the Ombudsmanâ€™s office assigned the case to an investigator who will be on leave until May 19th, while the second and final round of the election will take place just one day earlier, on May 18th.
The complaint follows multiple unanswered freedom of information requests from MCC Brussels regarding how the Commission was applying the DSA in Romaniaâ€™s electoral context, which the think tank claims were refused based on exemptions that do not apply in this case under EU law.
ğŸš¨ The EU Commission talks transparency but hides DSA proceedings on Romaniaâ€™s elections behind closed doors. MCC Brussels is calling them out with a formal complaint to the Ombudsman. Democracy deserves better.https://t.co/cTSkEMf2dl
MCC Brussels began investigating after former Commissioner Thierry Bretonâ€”the EUâ€™s so-called â€œcensorship czarâ€â€” talked about widespread DSA enforcement in national elections to ward off â€œforeign interference,â€ andÂ strongly hintedÂ that EU pressure could have played a role in the Romanian decision to cancel last yearâ€™s election following the first round victory of nationalist candidate CÄƒlin Georgescu.
The European Commission did confirm to MCC Brussels that there are two DSA proceedings linked to TikTok and Romania at the moment, but argued that it cannot disclose documents about ongoing investigations. According to the think tank, however, this exemption does not apply when the disclosure is in â€œsignificant public interestâ€â€”as it is obviously the case now, with less than a week left until the election is repeatedâ€”particularly when it comes to potential foreign interference in a countryâ€™s democratic processes.
â€œThe Commissionâ€™s habit of ignoring uncomfortable questions past legal deadlines is well documented,â€ MCC Brussels Director Frank Furedi noted, referring to, among others, the EU Court of Auditorsâ€™Â recent ruling about the virtually non-existent EU transparency. As Furedi explained:
In this case, the timing is particularly suspect, with the next round of elections just days away. The Romanian people deserve to know what role the EU is playing in their democratic process. While we welcome the Ombudsmanâ€™s investigation, this must only be the beginning. Elected officials, the press, and the public must continue to demand accountability.
Thereâ€™s not much known about these proceedings so far, apart from them looking at TikTok and Romania, and that they were launched by the EU Commission around the same time as the first round of the canceled election.
One additional detail that MCC found buried on the Commissionâ€™s website is that days before the election, Brussels instructed TikTok to monitor and save all information related to the campaign. This would imply two things: first, the Commission was at least expecting some kind of foreign interference campaign; and secondly, the Commission should have all the data needed to conclusively prove or disprove the claim of Russian interference.
As we also reported,Â the election was canceledÂ by the since-resigned Romanian president, Klaus Iohannis, based on allegations from intelligence services that Georgescuâ€™s campaign was massively boosted by Russia on TikTok, which resulted in him winning first place. However, despite hundreds of thousands protesting on the streets and all opposition parties (both Left and Right) demanding public disclosure, no conclusive evidence supporting this claim has been presented to Romanians to date.
Meanwhile,Â a report published by investigative journalistsÂ revealed that at least one of the main campaigns that allegedly supported Georgescu on behalf of Russia on TikTok was in fact paid for and organized by the center-right PNLâ€”one of the main establishment parties in the current government and member of von der Leyenâ€™s EPP groupâ€”in a failed attempt to divert votes from their main opponent.
The EU Commissionâ€™s DSA probe, therefore, should also offer some insight into whether this was truly the case. However, with the Ombudsman dragging her feet and delaying the investigation until right after the election, there is no chance the documents would be released in time to make any difference.
Although itâ€™s worth noting that this would probably be the case even if the Ombudsman were taking the complaint seriously, as her rulings are not binding. The Previous Ombudsman, Emily Oâ€™Reilly,Â reprimandedÂ the Commission (and von der Leyen personally) countless times for their violation of EU transparency rules, butÂ she was ignoredÂ just as everyone else.

title: See No Evil: Why Is Nobody in the Mainstream Asking Obvious Questions about These Nutters Who Keep Trying To Kill Trump?
author: By Raw Egg Nationalist
content:
I gave up on the whole â€œwhat if the boot was on the other footâ€ whine a long time ago, and so should you, frankly. Itâ€™s a waste of air. There are moral asymmetries in politics today that no amount of gurgling and mewling will do anything to change. How leftists gleefully do everything in their power to lock up, destroy, even kill their opponents, then scream blue murder as soon as they get one-hundredth of their hate thrown back at them when theyâ€™re no longer in powerâ€”thatâ€™s one example that springs to mind. Youâ€™re literally killing democracy! Which is to say, doing exactly what we do, just less ruthlessly and effectively. But, anyway, indulge me for a moment here. What if the boot really was on the other foot?
What ifâ€”oh, I donâ€™t knowâ€”a plot to assassinate President Barack Obama was uncovered? What if it involved a neo-Nazi teenager in the US who had been conspiring with a foreign actor from a country the US was bankrolling in a massive war? And what if the plot existed because the President had now decided it would be better for the war, finally, to come to an end?
Do you think that would be a big story?
I think it would. It sounds like the plot of a Tom Clancy novel come to life. And imagine wanting to harm Barack Obama!
Well, guess what? I didnâ€™t just pull that scenario out of my backsideâ€”or Tom Clancyâ€™s. There really is a transatlantic neo-Nazi plot to kill the President and it involves a close ally the US has bankrolled to the tune of hundreds of billions of dollars in a war thatâ€™s taking place right now, as I type out this article. The only difference is, the President is Donald Trump not Barack Obama, so nobodyâ€™s saying a damn thing about it. Oh yeah, and itâ€™s not that close ally the US has bankrolled to the tune of hundreds of billions of dollars eitherâ€”itâ€™s Ukraine.
The teenager in this shocking real case is one Nikita Casap. Seventeen-year-old Nikita was arrested in early March during a traffic stop in Kansas. He was driving a stolen vehicle, had a gun and ammunition, and a large quantity of money in his possession. A week or so earlier, police had arrived at the Casap family residence in Waukesha, Wisconsin to make a welfare check after his mother and stepfather hadnâ€™t been seen in two weeks. When there was no answer, officers entered the property and discovered their dead bodies. It was also discovered that a large quantity of personal items had been stolen.
Nikita was arrested for his mother and stepfatherâ€™s murders and for stealing and selling their stuff. When the FBI accessed his electronic devices, they discovered what the money was for. Little Nicky had been planning on buying heavy weaponryâ€”a drone and explosivesâ€”to assassinate Donald Trump and topple the government. Standard teenager things.
Itâ€™s an incredible story. You can read the FBIâ€™s documents on the case online. They contain screenshots from Telegram conversations Nikita had with a number of different individuals in Ukraine. In multiple conversations, Casap talks about killing Donald Trump using weapons obtained from his Ukrainian contacts and paid for with cryptocurrency; going into hiding in Ukraine after the assassination; and how the whole thing willâ€”convenientlyâ€”be blamed on the Russians. He talks about buying a drone with a special â€œdropper,â€ presumably to drop a bomb on the President, and asks whether heâ€™ll be able to live a normal life in Ukraine, even â€œwhen itâ€™s found out I did it [killed Trump].â€
There are also screenshots from a â€œmanifestoâ€â€”written by whom, itâ€™s not clearâ€”which outlines an â€œaccelerationalistâ€ project to bring about the final victory of the white race over its eternal desert-wandering, curly-locked arch-enemies.
â€œIt is clear that jews control all of the White countries, and it is clear that they promote White genocide and degeneracy. This [sic] for the white [sic] race to survive, it is necessary to accelerate the collapse of the countries. Jewish occupied governments must fall. The white race cannot survive unless America collapses.â€
President Trumpâ€™s murderâ€”and maybe the murder of his Vice President tooâ€”â€œis guaranteed to bring some chaos,â€ the manifesto continues. It will also â€œfurther bring into the public the idea that assassinations and accelerating the collapse are possible things to do.â€
All to the good, then.
There are references to various neo-Nazi groups in the material, from the Order of Nine Angles to Atomwaffen, both of which sound like factions from a shoddy mid-90s RTS game, except theyâ€™re not. Theyâ€™re real groups.
Reading all of this dreck, I couldnâ€™t help but feel sorry for young Nikita. Heâ€™s just a teenager, and he comes off as very naive, especially when heâ€™s asking if he can live a â€œnormal lifeâ€ in Ukraine when heâ€™s just killed the President of the worldâ€™s most powerful country with a bomb dropped from a drone. But nothing changes the fact he killed his mother and step-father in cold blood, took their stuff and sold it so he could kill the President, with the broader goal of killing even more people. Weâ€™re all impressionable as teenagers butâ€”bloody hell. This is a long way from Reefer Madness.
Like I say, all of this stuff is online, in the FBI documents, but nobody in the mainstream media is saying or doing a thing about it. At best, Casap will be dismissed as a lone-wolf loser, in spite of all the evidence to the contrary. At worst, heâ€™ll simply be ignored and forgotten.
Thereâ€™s a huge story here and it doesnâ€™t just involve Nikita Casap. It involves two other people who recently tried to assassinate Donald Trump: Thomas Matthew Crooks, the Butler gunman who came within millimeters of succeeding, and Ryan Routh, who lay in wait for the President while he was playing golf, a few weeks later.
Ryan Routhâ€™s connections to Ukraine are well known. He travelled there to recruit soldiers to fight the Russians, and had a grand plan to import Afghan refugees via Iran to that aim. Routh also had apparent connections to Ukrainian neo-Nazis. He appeared in a social-media video to drum up support for the Azov Battalionâ€™s Mariupol garrison; although Azov have, unsurprisingly, denied any association with him. Routh blamed Donald Trump for the war in Ukraine and believed that if he became president the war would be lost. So Trump had to die.
Thomas Matthew Crooks also had foreign connections, including encrypted messaging accounts on platforms based in Belgium, New Zealand and Germany. We still donâ€™t have a clue who he was talking to, but he was precisely the same kind of weird-ass teenage boy as Nikita Casap. Were they talking to the same people, in the same groups? Itâ€™s not beyond the realms of possibility.
You can choose to dismiss these people as whackos and assume theyâ€™re totally unconnected, lone wolves; or you can choose to see the similarities and pursue them.
The mainstream media is choosing not to see the similarities or pursue them. I think we know why.
So instead, itâ€™s being left to internet users like the sleuths behind the Substack page â€œEvents in Ukraineâ€ to try to draw some lines among all the dots. He does an admirable job; although the range of potential actors, ideologies and interests involved is rather daunting to someone who isnâ€™t as up on his Eastern European neo-Nazi groups as he really should be.
What is clear, I think, beyond a shadow of a doubt, is that thereâ€™s a real threat to the Presidentâ€™s life from factions within Ukraine that do not want peace with Russia. That threat will continue and may even grow if peace is concluded. Itâ€™s said that one reason Zelensky himself doesnâ€™t want peace, especially if heâ€™s forced to concede territory to the Russians, is because he knows heâ€™ll be a lifelong target for ultranationalists, regardless of which capital he chooses for his exile. Theyâ€™ll get him whether heâ€™s in London, Paris or Ougadougou.
This is a totally distinct threat from the threat posed to the President and members of the administration by the American left, which is now taking its cues from Luigi Mangione and his murder of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson. This is an international threat, for the purposes of influencing international politics, even if American citizens are used to carry it out.
If these people succeed, God forbid, that will be a story the media canâ€™t turn a blind eye to.
